resources.string: Already have an account? Sign in
Paper that can be recycled: newspapers, magazines, telephone books, office paper, junk mail, comics and light cardboard.
Preparation: Ensure items are clean from any organic material like food or grease.
Plastic that can be recycled: Plastic bottles, bottle tops and cartons.

Preparation: Plastic items placed in your recycling bin need to be clean, dry and loose. This means there should be no food or liquids left on/in your plastic items, and you should place all the items loosely in the bin
Tins/Cans that can be recycled: Drink cans, aluminion foil, soup/sauce/fruit tins, food cans, biscuit tins, pet food cans, beer bottle lids.

Preparation:Empty and rinse items – left over foods or liquids can contaminate other recyclables. You can leave labels on – these are removed in the recycling process. Metal lids and caps can also be placed in the household recycling bin.

Batteries that can be recycled: Household batteries (AA, AAA, C, C, 9-volt) can be brought to battery recycling stations. Stores like Aldi and Lidl have battery recycling stations in store - Look for the blue box at tills!
Glass that can be recycled: All types of glass: green, clear and brown are fine to recycle
Preparation: Clean, dry and loose. Some recycling banks will require separation of clear, green and brown glass.
Donate pre-loved garments, shoes and soft furnishings to local charity shops or use the charity textile bins at bring centres and other locations.

Preparation: Some textiles are not suitable for re-use or recycling such as those that are heavily soiled or worn, these should be disposed of in a clothes bank where they will be sent for shredding and used, for instance, as furniture stuffing.
